Sample K HDS (mmolh−1 g−1) CO uptake (μmolg−1) TOF (10−3 s−1) NiMo/GO 0.20 – – NiMo/TiO2 0.26 61.0 36.8 NiMo/TGC-0.25 0.39 – – NiMo/TGC-0.5 0.76 16.3 172.8 NiMo/TGC-1.0 0.43 – – NiMo catalysts supported on graphene-modified mesoporous TiO2 toward highly efficient hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene Huaiyuan Wang a ⁎ Bo Xiao a Xiaoshuang Cheng a Chijia Wang a Li Zhao a Yanji Zhu a Jiahua Zhu b Xiaohua Lu c a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northeast Petroleum University, Daqing 163318, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Northeast Petroleum University Daqing 163318 China b Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH 44221 USA Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering The University of Akron Akron OH 44221 USA c State Key Lab of Material-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing 210009, China State Key Lab of Material-Oriented Chemical Engineering Nanjing University of Technology Nanjing 210009 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 4596503498. Graphical abstract The graphene-covered mesoporous TiO2 (S BET >90m2 g−1) were successfully prepared by using graphene oxide (GO) as graphene source via one-step hydrothermal reduction, and then were prepared supported NiMo catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT). The active species were incorporated by incipient impregnation. Compared with the unmodified NiMo/TiO2 catalyst, all modified catalysts exhibited higher HDS activity under mild conditions of 280°C, 2.0MPa, liquid hourly space velocity of 4h−1 and hydrogen/feed ratio of 400 (V/V). Among of them, the catalyst with the appropriate mass ratio of rGO/TiO2(0.5) showed the highest DBT conversion of 99.9%. The prepared catalysts were characterized by various techniques (N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, Raman, Pyridine FT-IR, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, CO uptake, SEM and TEM). The enhanced HDS activity can be ascribed to (i) The incorporation of rGO (reduced graphene oxide) induces proper enhanced Lewis acidity of the modified catalysts, which promotes the adsorption of DBT molecules and facilitates the hydrogenation route. (ii) The introduction of rGO changes the HDS product (H2S) desorption behaviors, accelerating H2S desorption rate from catalyst surface and promoting the efficiency of catalyst immediately. Keywords Mesoporous TiO2 Graphene oxide Hydrothermal reduction Hydrodesulfurization 1 Introduction Environmental concerns are forcing dramatic challenge in transportation fuel specifications as sulfur-containing compounds in motor fuel are closely related to the emission of SOx, which is the main reason of air pollution. To meet the increasing stringent environmental regulations, deep/ultra-deep desulfurization are in urgent demanding [1–4]. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is one of the most widely used techniques for removing sulfur-containing compounds from petroleum products in the refining industry, where HDS catalyst plays a vital role in the determining process. Therefore, developing highly efficient catalyst exerts particularly important [5–7]. The support of catalyst is one of the key factors that impact its catalytic performance [8–10]. Recently, TiO2 has been recognized as a new generation of active support because of the moderate acid properties and the relatively weak interaction with the active metals, which is capable of improving the dispersion and reducibility of the supported active species [11,12]. However, the low surface area and poor thermal stability of traditional TiO2 limit its application. To overcome the above drawbacks, a new type of mesoporous TiO2 (anatase) whisker with high thermal stability (convert to rutile at 900°C), good mechanical property (>16.4Nmm−1) and large surface area (>90m2 g−1) was developed in our previous work [13]. The HDS performance of corresponding catalyst NiMo/TiO2 is investigated, but the result is not satisfactory. Generally, the catalytic performance is mainly determined by two factors: active sites and mass transfer of reaction on catalyst surface [14,15]. However, most current studies are focused on enhancing the activity of reactive sites and catalytic reaction mechanisms. It should be pointed out that mass transfer is equally important for the catalyst efficiency. According to the our previous molecular dynamics simulation [16], the key HDS resultant H2S (polar molecule) was prone to be absorbed on catalyst surface, which decreased the transfer rate of molecules off interfacial layer drastically and influenced the efficiency of NiMo/TiO2 directly. In recent years, many studies have reported the carbon-modified supports to prepare supported active metals catalysts using different materials as carbon sources, including phenyl-phosphonic acid (PPA), citric acid (CA) and monocarboxylic acids [17–19]. It shows that carbon modification on the surface of supports is also an alternative and effective way besides the conventional methods [20]. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no research reporting on graphene-doped TiO2 by surface modification in HDS reaction. Graphene, as one of the advanced carbon nano-materials, is a 2-dimensional single sheet of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal network. It has attracted a great deal of scientific interest and possess potentially applications in various fields, such as composite materials, batteries, solar cells and catalysts, due to its distinct properties [21–23]. Inspired from the above studies, we intend to use graphene to modify the surface of TiO2 support. But the solubility of graphene is poor, which is unfavorable for our work. Unlike graphene, graphene oxide (GO) is soluble due to the hydrophilic functional groups on the sheet surface, which render GO a good substitute for synthesizing new composite materials in liquid phase [24]. Herein, we first fabricated a reduced graphene oxide (rGO) surface modification on TiO2 support via one-step hydrothermal reduction method. Through adjusting TiO2 surface adsorption toward H2S molecule, an optimization was realized between diffusion and HDS process. Besides, the effects of rGO on the acidity of catalysts were investigated. Compared with the unmodified catalyst of NiMo/TiO2, the conversion of dibenzothiophene (DBT) increases from 78.6% to 99.9% under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Graphite powder (180 mesh) was purchased from Qing-dao Black Dragon Reagent Co. Ltd., (Qing dao, China). (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and C2H5OH (A.R.) were supplied by Tianjin Yaohua Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., (Tian jin, China). Decalin and CS2 (A.R. standard) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., Dibenzothiophene (C10H8S, 99.9%) was purchased from Acros Organics. Rapid hydrogen sulfide gas detector tube (200–5000ppm) was purchased from Beijing Environmental Applied Technology Research Centre. All the reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of GO, supports and catalysts GO was synthesized by the modified Hummers’ method [25]. TiO2 was synthesized by ion-exchange method described in the literature [13]. In short, K2Ti2O5 was firstly hydrolyzed to be titanate (H2Ti2O5) at the presence of hydrochloride (0.1M). Then, H2Ti2O5 was calcined in muffle oven at 500°C to obtain mesoporous TiO2 (anatase). TiO2-rGO composite (TGC) was synthesized via hydrothermal reduction based on modified Rajamathi's method [26,27]. Briefly, a desired mount of GO was placed in a mixed solvent of distilled water (20mL) and ethanol (10mL). After 1h ultrasonic, 2.0g TiO2 was added to the above GO solution and stirred for 2h to get a homogeneous suspension. Then the suspension was transferred to a 40mL Teflon-Sealed autoclave and maintained at 120°C in electric oven for 3h. Finally, the resulting composite was obtained by sedimentation, rinsed by deionized water for several times and dried at 60°C for 5h. The supports obtained were named as TGC-x (x represents the mass ratio of rGO/TiO2 in percentage, x =0.25, 0.5, 1.0). The active components were introduced by incipient impregnation with nickel nitrate hexahydrate (0.12g) and ammonium heptamolybdate (0.12g). Finally, the as-prepared powder was calcined at 500°C for 2h to obtain the NiMo/TGC catalyst loading with NiO(1.4wt.%)-MoO3(4.7wt.%), which was the precursor of the “Ni–Mo–S” active phase for HDS [28]. 2.3 Characterization methods Structural properties of samples were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption (at −196°C) in a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020M apparatus. And the average pore size was calculated by D≈4 V BJH/S BET. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were acquired using the Tensor 27 infrared spectrometer with dry KBr. The spectra were recorded from 400 to 4000cm−1 with a resolution of 2cm−1. Acidity of catalysts were analyzed by FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine using the Tensor 27. 10mg of a sample is pressed into a self-supporting wafer followed by evacuation at 350°C for 0.5h. After cooled down to 50°C, the background spectrum was recorded, the sample was exposed to 1μL pyridine for 0.5h until equilibration at the temperature of 50°C, after that the catalyst was heated in a linear rate of 10°C/min to 280°C. Subsequently, the samples were outgassed for 0.5h at 280°C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were obtained on a D/max-2200PC using Cu Kα radiation operated at 40kV, 30mA, and scan speed of 10°/min. Raman spectra were obtained using a Horiba HR 800 spectrometer, equipped with a charge coupled device (CCD) camera detector. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was performed using a JEM-1010 instrument supplied by JEOL. The surface morphological details were studied by scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-5600LV). NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) tests were carried out on a BELCAT-A apparatus (Ankersmid, Netherlands). The synthesized catalyst (0.33g, 20–40 mesh) was pretreated with a pure He flow from room temperature to 300°C at a rate of 10°C/min and then cooled down to room temperature. Then, NH3 adsorption was carried out at 35°C for 2h using a mixture gas of 5vol.% NH3/He, and subsequently purged by pure He to remove excessive and weakly adsorbed NH3. Finally, the catalyst was heated to 600°C at a rate of 10°C/min in pure He and desorption pattern was recorded. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) characterization was conducted on TP-5000 apparatus (Tianjin Xianquan Co., Ltd., China). 20mg sample was taken each time and the temperature was increased up to 900°C at a rate of 10°C/min, meanwhile, the gas mixture of 10vol.% H2/Ar was introduced at 20mL/min into the quartz reactor. Irreversible CO uptake measurements were used to estimate the active sites on the catalysts. Usually, 0.3g of sample was loaded into a quartz reactor and purged in He at 200°C for 3h. After cooling, pulses of CO in He carrier at 40cm3 (NTP)min−1 were injected at room temperature through a sampling valve. CO uptake was calculated by measuring the decrease in the peak areas caused by adsorption in comparison with the area of a calibrated volume. 2.4 Catalytic activities The DBT HDS activity tests were conducted in a continuous fixed-bed reactor with 0.7g catalyst. Prior to the reaction, all fresh catalysts were sulfided in a mixture of 2wt.% CS2-cyclohexane at 350°C for 4h under 3.0MPa H2 pressure. After sulfidation, the temperature and pressure were decreased to reaction conditions of 280°C and 2.0MPa, the DBT feedstock with a concentration of 1300ppm (decalin was used as solvent) was fed into reactor under conditions liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 4h−1 and hydrogen/feed ratio 400 (V/V). 5h later, when the steady reaction conditions had been achieved, H2S detector tube was installed at the position (16th) in Fig. 1 to detect the density of H2S desorption in the next 5h, meanwhile, liquid samples were collected hourly and analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC-14C) installed with a flame ionization detector and a 30m KB-1 capillary column. The DBT molecules undergo HDS through two parallel reaction routes: direct desulfurization (DDS) and hydrogenation desulfurization (HYD) [29,30]. Biphenyl (BP) and cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) correspond to the main product of the above processes, respectively. In the experiment, the detected main products are BP and CHB, the HDS conversion and the selectivity for HYD path could be defined as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) Conversion of DBT= DBT in − DBT out DBT in × 100 % (2) HYD of selectivity= CHB DBT in − DBT out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties The nitrogen adsorption isotherms of the catalysts and their corresponding Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distributions determined from the adsorption branch are exhibited in Fig. 2 . The isotherm pattern of all catalysts present the typical adsorption characteristics of IUPAC V, the NiMo/GO shows obvious H4 type hysteresis loop due to layer structure. However, the other catalysts exhibit typical H3 type hysteresis loop at relative high pressure (0.8< P/P 0 <0.99), suggesting that the as-prepared material is sheet/virgate and possesses mesoporous structure [31,32]. Besides, compared with NiMo/TiO2, the modified catalysts show almost no vertical shifts between P/P 0 =0.8 and 0.99, which can be attributed to the pore structure changes slightly indicating that there is no blockage of the mesoporous TiO2 [33] and this is also verified in BET. BET surface area (S BET), pore volume (V BJH), and average pore diameter of different modified supports and catalyst are shown in Table 1 . The original TiO2 shows the largest S BET of 102.5m2 g−1. With the incorporation of rGO, the S BET of modified supports decrease slightly indicating that rGO has a good dispersion on TiO2. Moreover, after the impregnation of active component, the S BET of corresponding catalysts decrease in a limited extent. Compared with supports, the V BJH and pore size of the corresponding catalysts do not change obviously. These results show that the incorporation of active components do not affect the pore accessibility of all supports and block the pores [33]. 3.2 FT-IR FTIR spectra of GO and supports are shown in Fig. 3 . The characterization method is usually used to detect the changes of functional groups after materials modification. The broad absorptions below 1000cm−1 are attributed to the vibration of TiOTi, the absorptions at 974cm−1 for the modified supports are weaker than that for the pure TiO2, which is mainly due to the partially coverage of the surface of TiO2 by the rGO sheets. The absorption bonds (curve of modified supports and GO) appearing at 1365 and 1620cm−1 are ascribed to CC stretching vibrations. Moreover, the absorption at 1690cm−1 (curve GO) is assigned to the CO stretching vibration [34] and it is absent in all the other supports, which indicates that GO is entirely reduced to rGO during the hydrothermal process [26]. The above results confirm the coexistence of TiO2 and rGO in the composite. 3.3 XRD Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of catalysts-fresh. As shown in Fig. 4, the above four samples show diffraction peaks at 25.3°, 37.8°, 48°, 53.9°, 55.1°, 62.6° and 75.2°, which are ascribed to the diffraction of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 21-1272). The bottom curve is NiMo/GO, the peak around 13° is assigned as diffraction of GO, and peak around 28° is attributed to the diffraction of graphite. No peaks of NiMo phases are observed in Fig. 4, which is due to the high dispersion of NiMo species on the supports and this is consistent with the Nitrogen adsorption–desorption results. Moreover, no diffraction peaks for graphene are exhibited in the curves of the modified catalysts, which is attributed to the low amount and relatively low diffraction intensity of graphene [25]. Furthermore, it can be concluded that the incorporation of rGO does not change the crystalline phase of TiO2. 3.4 Raman Raman spectroscopy is widely used to determine the state of oxide (Mo and Ni) loaded on the supports. As presented in Fig. 5 , typical anatase bonds at 395, 515, 640cm−1 are observed [35,36]. In the lower frequency region, the bands at 244cm−1 are assigned to the deformation vibration of the MoOMo bridges in polymolybdate surface while the bands around 300cm−1 are due to the bending vibrations of MoO in either Mo7O24 6− or Mo8O26 4− [37,38]. The NiMo oxide species emerge mainly at the higher frequency region, for all catalysts, the peaks arising at 750–1050cm−1 are attributed to Mo species [37]. The peaks at 800cm−1 are originated from the species of MoO4 2− [39]. The peaks at 948 and 958cm−1 are attributed to the symmetric and antisymmetric MoO terminal stretches of Mo7O24 6− and Mo8O26 4−, respectively [37,39,40]. However, the Mo7O24 6− peak at 948cm−1 is weaker, which implies that the amount of Mo7O24 6− is smaller than that of Mo8O26 4−. Moreover, the existence of some NiMoO4 species (Raman bands at 948 and 958cm−1) cannot be excluded [41,42]. Compared with the unmodified catalysts, the new peaks at 875cm−1 can be ascribed to the β-NiMoO4 phase, which is considered easier to be reduced than α-NiMoO4 and shows better catalytic properties [41]. Meanwhile, the well-defined bonds for crystalline MoO3 at 667, 818, 996cm−1 are not appeared, which imply that highly dispersion of Mo oxide species in the as-prepared NiMo/TGC catalysts [43–45]. And the results are consistent with the XRD characterization results. In addition, curve b, c and d show the presence of D and G bond of graphene indicating that the successful incorporation of rGO to the modified catalyst [46], and this is consistent with the FT-IR results. 3.5 NH3-TPD and Pyridine FT-IR NH3-TPD is widely used to measure the acidic properties of catalysts, as NH3 is a strong base and can interact with OH species on catalyst, which represent the acidity of samples. The absorption of NH3 can be divided into two models as the physical absorption and the chemical absorption. The effect of rGO on the acidity of catalysts is exhibited in Fig. 6 a, the desorbed NH3 below 105°C is attributed to the physically absorbed NH3 while the chemically absorbed NH3 is desorbed between 105 and 610°C. Based on the temperature at which adsorbed NH3 desorbs, the acid sites are classified as weak (<230°C), medium (230–430°C) and strong (>430°C) acid sites [47]. Obviously, an intensive desorption peak (marked in red circle) is observed in demonstrating the increase of medium acid sites and the type of acid will be discussed later. In order to investigate the acid types of catalysts, Pyridine FT-IR analysis is adopted. Generally, the adsorption of pyridine molecules are classified into three types: (i) the protonation of pyridine characterizes the Brönsted acid sites, showing adsorption bonds around 1540 and 1630cm−1; (ii) the coordination between pyridine molecules and the Lewis acid sites giving adsorption bonds at 1440–1460, 1575–1580, 1600–1620cm−1; (iii) the weak hydrogen bond between pyridine and hydroxy groups, which exhibits adsorption bonds around 1447 and 1590cm−1 [48]. As shown in Fig. 6b, NiMo/TGC-x show adsorption bands at 1447, 1490, 1558 and 1607cm−1. The bands at 1447 and 1607cm−1 are attributed to Lewis acid sites [49], with the increasing of x, the Lewis acid sites increase at first and reach a maximum at x =0.5 then decrease. Duan et al. [50] assigned the bond at 1490cm−1 to pyridine adsorption of both Lewis acid and Brönsted acid sites. The absorption bands at 1558cm−1 are due to Brönsted acid sites, which exhibit no significant changes with the increasing of x. In summary, NH3-TPD analysis shows the overall acidity of modified catalysts increase in different degree. Among of them, the acidity of NiMo/TGC-0.5 increases at a maximum, but NH3-TPD cannot give the types of the increased acid sites. Pyridine FT-IR exhibits that the acid sites increase mainly in the form of Lewis acid (Table 2 , column 3), which is likely to facilitate the DBT molecules adsorption on catalysts and promote the HYD route. 3.6 H2-TPR H2-TPR is adopted to inquire more characteristics into Ni and Mo oxide on the surface of catalyst and their changes with the composition of support. TPR characterization results are shown in Fig. 7 , all of catalysts exhibit reduction peak at 340–360°C, the temperature peak is usually assigned to the first step of reduction(Mo6+–Mo4+) of polymeric octahedral Mo species bonded to TiO2 surface weakly[51]. The higher temperature with a maxima 600–800°C is ascribed to the second step of reduction(Mo4+–Mo0) of polymeric octahedral Mo and isolated tetrahedral Mo species interacted with the support strongly[52,53]. It should be noted that with the catalyst modified with rGO, the reduction temperature in high temperature region declines at least 150°C. This indicates the incorporation of rGO can weaken the interaction between active component and support, thereby reduce the reduction temperature for active species. 3.7 TEM and SEM The microphotographs of GO, TiO2 support, NiMo/TiO2 and NiMo/TGC-0.5 are shown in Fig. 8 . The synthesized GO nanosheet is investigated by TEM in Fig. 8a, which shows a semitransparent micro-surface with a few thin ripples. As reported previously, the ripples are intrinsic properties of thin GO sheets [54], which are due to the extra thermodynamic stability of the 2D nanosheets arising from microscopic crumpling. The as-prepared TiO2 (Fig. 8b) possesses a length/diameter ratio of 20, which is also called whisker. This is accordance with the results of nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms. After the impregnation of Mo and Ni species, NiMo/TGC-0.5 maintains the whisker morphology (Fig. 8c), but the surface becomes rough. The TEM of fresh NiMo/TiO2 and NiMo/TGC-0.5 are shown in Fig. 8d and e, through careful observation, it can be obtained that the active species deposited on the modified catalyst shows better dispersion than NiMo/TiO2. Low-resolution TEM image of NiMo/TGC-0.5-spent is exhibited in Fig. 8f, which shows the diameter of matrix is around 50nm. Fig. 8g and 8h show the high-resolution TEM images of NiMo/TGC-0.5-spent. It can be observed (Fig. 8g) that, the active species arranges closely and has a good dispersion on the support, which is due to the weak interaction between active metals and support. In the high magnification TEM micrographs (Fig. 8h), the well-known NiMoS slabs (marked by arrows) are observed, exhibiting multilayer stacking structure, which are the true reaction active centers and considered to have a good deep HDS performance [55]. 3.8 XPS Fig. 9 a shows the XPS profiles of the Ni 2p region of sulfided NiMo/TiO2 and NiMo/TGC-0.5. The Ni 2p envelope is consist of a mixture with three substances (NiS, NiO and NiMoS) [56]. The binding energy of NiS for the two catalyst are around 875eV, the peak emerging at 861eV is attributed to NiO and the peak of NiMoS appears at 855eV [57,58]. It should be mentioned that the modified catalyst shows a higher peak of NiMoS. The Mo 3d XPS of sulfided NiMo/TiO2 and NiMo/TGC-0.5 are presented in Fig. 9b. Generally, the signals of Mo 3d include Mo4+(MoS2), Mo5+(oxysulfide) and Mo6+(oxide) [59], each of Mo species appears in pairs such as, Mo 3d5/2 and 3d3/2. The deconvolution peaks of Mo 3d5/2 for Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+ are around 229eV, 230eV, 232.5eV, respectively. The binding energies values of Mo 3d3/2 are fixed 3.1eV more than those of Mo 3d5/2. Moreover, the peak appearing about 226eV is ascribed to the S 2s line. It is noted that the Mo4+ ratio of NiMo/TGC-0.5 catalyst is higher than that of NiMo/TiO2. In conclusion, an appropriate of rGO can promote the formation of active sites and enhance the efficiency of desulfurization. 3.9 CO uptake The k HDS, CO uptake and TOF of different catalysts are presented in Table 3 . Among of them,CO uptake is undertaken over the spent catalyst at room temperature to evaluate the active sites on catalyst. The k HDS and TOF are calculated by K HDS = − F W ln ( 1 − y ) and TOF = F W y M , respectively, where F is the rate of DBT fed into the reactor (μmols−1), w is mass of catalyst (g), y is the conversion of DBT and M is the active sites deposited on catalyst decided by CO uptake [49,60]. As can be seen in Table 3, the higher conversion of DBT corresponding to a higher value of K HDS, and the NiMo/TGC-0.5 catalyst shows the maximum of 0.76. The CO uptake amount of NiMo/TGC-0.5 is lower than that of NiMo/TiO2, however, and it possesses relatively higher TOF value, which indicates rGO sheets play an indispensable role in HDS reaction. 3.10 Hydrodesulfurization The activities of different catalysts were investigated under relative mild conditions (280°C, 2.0MPa). As shown in Fig. 10 a, the conversion of DBT increases with x and reaches a maximum conversion of 99.9% at x =0.5. With the further increase of x, the conversion of DBT decreases slightly, which may arise from the loss of synergistic effect between the support and active species due to the excess incorporation of rGO. Moreover, the selectivity of catalysts show a similar trend and this is attributed to the Lewis acid sites of NiMo/TGC change in different degree, as the Lewis acid site can serve as the DBT adsorption sites and improve the HYD route. 100h stability of NiMo/TiO2 and NiMo/TGC-0.5 catalyst are presented in Fig. 10b, samples are collected at the 5thh (starting time when pump is turned on). As shown in Fig. 10b, the HDS performance of NiMo/TGC-0.5 is stable at a value of 99.9% in the reaction 100h. As a comparison sample, NiMo/TiO2 is also considered in the long term stability experiment and exhibits a stable value of 78.8%. On the basis of the above experimental results and theoretical analyses, a possible catalytic mechanism of DBT on NiMo/TGC-0.5 is proposed and explain the increase in activity in two aspects. (i) During the HDS process, hydrogen molecules dissociate into hydrogen atoms on the active sites of the catalyst [61], and then transfer to adjacent surface of support by spillover and diffusion. Meanwhile, DBT molecules can be absorbed on active metal sites and Lewis acid sites. The former are assigned as DBTa and they undergo HDS via direct desulfurization (DDS). The latter are named as DBTb and they undergo HDS via hydrogenation (HYD). As the Lewis acid sites of NiMo/TGC-0.5 increase the most (Table 2, column 3), more DBTb are absorbed on the Lewis acid sites (Fig. 11 b) undergoing HDS via HYD. Finally, when the dissociative hydrogen atoms flow over the active sites, they participate in hydrogenation reaction and form the resultant of H2S, realizing deep desulfurization. (ii) As mentioned previously, our molecular dynamics simulation showed that polar molecule tended to be absorbed on mesoporous TiO2, which would influence the activity of catalysts definitely [16]. Li et al. [17] found that the surface of carbon-modified TiO2 possessed excellent hydrophobic property, which can weaken the adsorption of polar molecules and accelerate their transfer. This is beneficial to the reaction whose product is polar molecule, such as the HDS. Consequently, a graphene modification on TiO2 support is proposed to accelerate the desorption of product H2S, promote HDS reaction moving forward and enhance the HDS performance. The rapid gas (H2S) detector tube is used to measure the H2S desorption rate from catalysts, as exhibited the inset in Fig. 11 (under 5h steady-state of HDS reaction), the tube gives a value of 2000ppm for the unmodified catalyst, whereas the NiMo/TGC-0.5 is 4200ppm. The result indicates that the H2S desorption rate from catalyst surface is faster in the presence of rGO sheets. And this is also an important reason for improving the activity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, we examined the influence of graphene heterogeneous surface modification on the HDS performance of TiO2-supported catalyst and found the improving effect of graphene addition for the first time. Through adjusting TiO2 surface adsorption toward H2S molecule, realizing an optimization between diffusion and HDS process. The presence of rGO changes the desorption behaviors of product H2S molecules-accelerating their transfer rate on catalysts, and promotes reaction moving forward. In addition, the incorporation of graphene induces an enhanced Lewis acid site, which facilitates the adsorption of DBT molecules and promotes the HYD route. When the mass ratio of rGO/TiO2 is 0.5 in percentage, the corresponding catalyst shows the best HDS activity. Compared with the unmodified catalyst, the DBT conversion of NiMo/TGC-0.5 increases from 78.6% to 99.9% under relative mild conditions of 280°C, 2.0MPa, LHSV 4h−1, and hydrogen/feed ratio of 400 (V/V). Our present work shows that the heterogeneous modification on the surface of materials is an effective and alternative way to open a new possibility in the investigation of TiO2-rGO composites and promote their practical application in addressing various environmental issues. coredata.dc:description: The graphene-covered mesoporous TiO2 (S BET >90m2 g−1) were successfully prepared by using graphene oxide (GO) as graphene source via one-step hydrothermal reduction, and then were prepared supported NiMo catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT). The active species were incorporated by incipient impregnation. Compared with the unmodified NiMo/TiO2 catalyst, all modified catalysts exhibited higher HDS activity under mild conditions of 280°C, 2.0MPa, liquid hourly space velocity of 4h−1 and hydrogen/feed ratio of 400 (V/V). Among of them, the catalyst with the appropriate mass ratio of rGO/TiO2(0.5) showed the highest DBT conversion of 99.9%. The prepared catalysts were characterized by various techniques (N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, Raman, Pyridine FT-IR, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, CO uptake, SEM and TEM). The enhanced HDS activity can be ascribed to (i) The incorporation of rGO (reduced graphene oxide) induces proper enhanced Lewis acidity of the modified catalysts, which promotes the adsorption of DBT molecules and facilitates the hydrogenation route. (ii) The introduction of rGO changes the HDS product (H2S) desorption behaviors, accelerating H2S desorption rate from catalyst surface and promoting the efficiency of catalyst immediately.
coredata.dc:title: NiMo catalysts supported on graphene-modified mesoporous TiO2 toward highly efficient hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene
